conclusion: To calculate the distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds, analyze the acceleration-time graph and use kinematic equations.
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the car accelerates at 2 m/s².
From t = 10 to t = 30 seconds, the car moves at a constant velocity (acceleration is 0).
From t = 30 to t = 60 seconds, the car decelerates at -1 m/s².
Initial velocity (v0) is 0 m/s since the car starts from rest.
Velocity at t = 10 seconds is 20 m/s.
Velocity at t = 30 seconds is 20 m/s (constant velocity).
Velocity at t = 60 seconds is -10 m/s.
Distance from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds is 100 m.
Distance from t = 10 to t = 30 seconds is 400 m.
Distance from t = 30 to t = 60 seconds is 150 m.
The car travels a total distance of 650 meters within 60 seconds.
